New Brazilian buffet tour

This one is interesting because it's inside a church

Brazil (like South America) is VERY religious, 87% of the population is Christian

tweets.text:
I think the inconvenient truth that a lot of software engineers are coming to realize right now is that what they've been working on is just not all that hard.

The solution is to start working on harder things.

@dwlz Reframing

A lot of what engineers built wasn’t easy, it was just standardized. Now AI is compressing that layer.

So it’s less about “work harder” and more about:

Work on deeper problems.
Own outcomes, not just tasks.
Build leverage.

The bar is rising, that’s the opportunity.

tweets.text:
Introducing GLM-5: From Vibe Coding to Agentic Engineering

GLM-5 is built for complex systems engineering and long-horizon agentic tasks. Compared to GLM-4.5, it scales from 355B params (32B active) to 744B (40B active), with pre-training data growing from 23T to 28.5T tokens. https://t.co/uGYQUjIbbs

@Zai_org 700+ tool calls in a single session is the real benchmark here. every other model tops out around 50 before context degrades. curious what the failure mode looks like at call 400 though, does it gracefully degrade or just start hallucinating tool schemas?

notes: Flagged by @rameerez as 'Blocked for AI reply'

tweets.text:
Chrome is working on WebMCP

OpenClaw's biggest problem (and any AI agent's) when using a browser is that it's TOO slow and dumb

Opens a tab, waits 3s, then navigates to the page, waits 5s, then takes a screenshot, waits 2s, then scrolls, waits...

WebMCP solves this

The

@rameerez WebMCP in Chrome 146 is a game-changer. AI agents querying and executing services directly without browsing like a human removes the biggest bottleneck in web automation.

Declarative service discovery via navigator.modelContext means any website can become an API for agents.
@Strakyo blocked for AI reply
